Hey, I've found out that they deprecated the onAttach() function of the Fragment class.

Instead of:

onAttach (Activity activity)

It's now:

onAttach (Context context)
I want to call a method from fragment interface to my Activity,  any thought on this?
^^ My current approach
v4 fragments or native?
native
wont be called on preLollipop
Test API 17
Context can be casted to an activity, but I still don’t recommend that way of communicating. Use a bus, use Rx, use an interface
<http://stackoverflow.com/questions/32604552/onattach-not-called-in-fragment>

let’s say you have HomeActivity and AnotherActivity.
You have a method called fooMyBar() in HomeActivity and you call it from the fragment. The activity can be null, enjoy your crash. Or then you want to add it to Another Activity. You have to check if it’s null, then check which instanceof is it, then cast it , then call.

text: ^ this section was written as a hardcore troll to all android developers
it was never a good idea
it will never be a good idea
singletons are the answer?
and frankly that page should have never been written like that as it is misleading on best practices and junior level nonsense
<@U0EJWJWRK>: not blanket answer but yes they can be
otto is good, eventbus would be good if they got rid of some of the dumb stuff
you can use the rxbus as suggested too
rx is bulky
ive built entire apps with just local broadcasts
oh, my - it had to be a hell (broadcasts, i mean) - without appropriate architecture. Pub sub seems like exposing too much to all app.
what's wrong with accessing activity from fragment through interface/casting/checks/etc.? what is the weak point?
broadcasts is fine, use interfaces to define the permissible broadcasts and write utilities to validate receiving side got what it should have got
i wrote several apps like that and they are still in use today and work great
its not weak so much as its anti pattern
your fragment is now coupled to your activity which is the exact opposite of its intent
you don’t write views that require a callback from the activity
so you shouldnt write fragments like that which are really just complex views
<@U055GGAHS>: +1 for local broacasts
+1 for <@U08GFT5V5>
<@U08GFT5V5>: :taco:
<@U055GGAHS>: :taco:

interface making it weak couple (like men&women=), every fragment lives inside activity just deal with it, you will always have one to control its fragments (read implement some interface). Fragment does not know nothing about its activity. Nothing will be missed. Also for juniors its all very clear in case of Android framework - cause of lifecycles
I’m not sure with broadcasts/otto/eventbus - they are handy, but has to be controlled strictly, like u sad permissible broadcasts and validation - more work do to in all points of connection.
that is only if you use broadcasts, use something like eventbus then that is a non issue
but if you really want interface callbacks that are required at runtime go for it

its been my experience that the more code you add to fragments and activities the worse things get for you though so I try to keep them as minimal as possible and required interfaces with runtime implementation checking doesn’t help that cause

I’m just trying to protect the pattern cause also in my experience, I  had no problems with it, as no problems with otto/rx approach, so I’ve asked what weak point did you expose, just to be sure that do not missing something.

Like i said, if you really want to do it that way by all means do it that way. The vast majority of senior developers will disagree with you though so just be warned that regardless of any specific persons opinion, the majority rule is that you should not do it which may cause you friction later on.

> The vast majority of senior developers will disagree
is it personal opinion or you were voting somewhere?
Am senior developer, do not recommend tightly coupling through interfaces

> by all means do it that way
I have this options and glad to have, cause really in some places its enough.
<@U0EJWJWRK>: lol no there’s not official vote but just go read stack overflow and like any blog
you wont find any devs at facebook, twitter, square, etc advocating doing it that way
they will almost all be on RX or otto

>at facebook
:troll:
<@U055GGAHS>: nah nah, we set the official Android dev rules and guidelines every February 29th here in <#C055R54EU>, remember?
i doubt you will find many if any senior devs here doing it that way either
you do not need ugly things with broadcasts, thirdparty libs, singletons. Right pattern for right places
lol alright
you do you
<@U055GGAHS>: I’ve found senior devs that recommended that way :troll:
But that might just be what you define “senior” :stuck_out_tongue_winking_eye:
are they senior in age? :stuck_out_tongue:
lol

at the end of the day i dont care

other people will have other opinions and that is fine

so new question, should i have a component for each presenter ?
say, i have my NetworkingComponent
and it’s used from different presenters
should i have a component for each presenter, or just create networking component in each presenter ?
are you doing dagger2+mortar+flow?
just dagger 2
i just have one
depending on what you’re doing you could `@Singleton` the component too.
if your presenters need specific things not in the NetworkingComponent you could make a ConcretePresenterComponent that includes the NetworkingModule backing the Component.
you have just one what? one presentercomponent ?

sorry, one NetworkingComponent. I use Firebase for my networking / api calls. So I have a FirebaseModule. Even though I have a one to one presenter to PresenterComponent relationship  setup, most of my presenters need the FirebaseModule. So one of my presenter’s PresenterComponent would have this to include the FirebaseModule: `@Component(modules={FirebaseModule.class})`

public static Bitmap resizeImage(Bitmap source, int w, int h) {
        int width = source.getWidth();
        int height = source.getHeight();
        float scaleWidth = ((float) w) / width;
        float scaleHeight = ((float) h) / height;
